text: <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> Very long odds winners are fun but I doubt they're anyone's bread and butter. You certainly shouldn't be blindly backing all 1000 shots or anything silly like that.

elements.text: Very long odds winners are fun but I doubt they're anyone's bread and butter. You certainly shouldn't be blindly backing all 1000 shots or anything silly like that.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> I also find that Chester is shit on the data for my strategy. Along with Lingfield. I have long since been suspicious of the way TPD calculate the distance to the finish based on the running line. I notice strange anomalies in races where horses run wide etc.

elements.text: I also find that Chester is shit on the data for my strategy. Along with Lingfield. I have long since been suspicious of the way TPD calculate the distance to the finish based on the running line. I notice strange anomalies in races where horses run wide etc.

text: Do you calculate an alternative version <@U05N9773A23>? I used to but ultimately found theirs better.

elements.text: Do you calculate an alternative version
? I used to but ultimately found theirs better.

text: You could always calculate that yourself using the kml files <@U05N9773A23>

elements.text: You could always calculate that yourself using the kml files

text: I don't have access to those files otherwise I would. <@UGV299K6H> Perhaps it's a coincidence then, I just get frustrated with how often my model is making poor decisions due to errors in the data. Though I suppose if it was that good they wouldn't have made it available :joy:

elements.text: I don't have access to those files otherwise I would.

Perhaps it's a coincidence then, I just get frustrated with how often my model is making poor decisions due to errors in the data. Though I suppose if it was that good they wouldn't have made it available

text: I have to admit that when I watch "replays" of the race GPS feed I often witness unexplained lateral (as in perpendicular to current velocity vector) movement that is not apparent in a video replay of the race. But measurement error has always occurred and in all honesty I do think it has improved.

elements.text: I have to admit that when I watch "replays" of the race GPS feed I often witness unexplained lateral (as in perpendicular to current velocity vector) movement that is not apparent in a video replay of the race. But measurement error has always occurred and in all honesty I do think it has improved.

text: Interesting, I was looking at this the other day, it would have to be very far off for us all to be losing money, the track is different to the 'norm'

elements.text: Interesting, I was looking at this the other day, it would have to be very far off for us all to be losing money, the track is different to the 'norm'

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> Trust me, if you really dig into the data, there's plenty of anomalies. There's many instances of horses going backwards in my dataset :joy:

elements.text: Trust me, if you really dig into the data, there's plenty of anomalies. There's many instances of horses going backwards in my dataset

text: I did notice that sharp curvature just after the finish line <@U4H19D1D2>. I believe (from twitter noise) that Chester also has a significant draw bias but I can't believe that is not accounted for in SP.

elements.text: I did notice that sharp curvature just after the finish line
. I believe (from twitter noise) that Chester also has a significant draw bias but I can't believe that is not accounted for in SP.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> It's to do with the way the trackers and tracking work, it's not as simple as just taking a GPS position, there's also an accelerometer in them and the data from the GPS and the accelerometer are stitched together and smoothed by TPD themselves.

elements.text: It's to do with the way the trackers and tracking work, it's not as simple as just taking a GPS position, there's also an accelerometer in them and the data from the GPS and the accelerometer are stitched together and smoothed by TPD themselves.

text: <@U05N9773A23> why can't you access the KML files?

elements.text: why can't you access the KML files?

text: Anyone with a running watch will know that just using GPS doesn't work that well.

elements.text: Anyone with a running watch will know that just using GPS doesn't work that well.

text: Yeah I believe that there is a kalman filter in operation in the hardware. I got that from a TPD employee so I doubt that is bullshit but you never know....

elements.text: Yeah I believe that there is a kalman filter in operation in the hardware. I got that from a TPD employee so I doubt that is bullshit but you never know....

text: It’s interesting i know people have data snd strategies that work differently on different tracks but I’ve always thought what’s the difference?! A circle or a straight line, all the horses are running together! I can see maybe on an individual horse basis it could make a difference say a horse has bad vision in its right eye and so doesn’t like turning right…..!

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> Yeah I don't know exactly how it all works but I do know that it's complicated. I've spoken with TPD about it quite a bit, it's not a secret.

elements.text: Yeah I don't know exactly how it all works but I do know that it's complicated. I've spoken with TPD about it quite a bit, it's not a secret.

text: I think if you're dealing with fundamentals <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> then it makes sense to factor in the environment. I'm no tennis modeller, but I'd imagine that clay court stats for a player are less impactful than grass courts when modelling wimbledon prices.

elements.text: I think if you're dealing with fundamentals
then it makes sense to factor in the environment. I'm no tennis modeller, but I'd imagine that clay court stats for a player are less impactful than grass courts when modelling wimbledon prices.

text: To be fair it looks more like the "backwards" movement is a correction.

text: You are using the TPD feed that plugs in to OTS software aren't you ?? That won't match up with my records but as <@UGV299K6H> says it looks like a correction. I don't know the details, but if they are running a Kalman filter in the mix somewhere and there is an element of forward prediction when calculating that value then it might make sense. There is no way to know though :man-shrugging:

elements.text: You are using the TPD feed that plugs in to OTS software aren't you ?? That won't match up with my records but as

says it looks like a correction. I don't know the details, but if they are running a Kalman filter in the mix somewhere and there is an element of forward prediction when calculating that value then it might make sense. There is no way to know though

text: I spent way too long trying to identify and "explain" odd glitches like this. Your time is your own to spend but I'd advise don't waste as much as I did looking into this stuff. It ultimately gets you nowhere and ALL measurement has some level of uncertainty attached to it. Better to just make the most of it when it is decent.

elements.text: I spent way too long trying to identify and "explain" odd glitches like this. Your time is your own to spend but I'd advise don't waste as much as I did looking into this stuff. It ultimately gets you nowhere and ALL measurement has some level of uncertainty attached to it. Better to just make the most of it when it is decent.

text: Agreed, I have found the more you try and do with the data the worse it gets, keep it as raw as possible, there are going to be errors but considering you are against users who are betting almost blind it doesn't really matter

elements.text: Agreed, I have found the more you try and do with the data the worse it gets, keep it as raw as possible, there are going to be errors but considering you are against users who are betting almost blind it doesn't really matter
